articles.headline: The Fight Over Flexible Spending Accounts
articles.snippet: To help pay for a health care bill, one proposal involves capping the amount people can put into special accounts for health-related spending.
articles.abstract: To help pay for a health care bill, one proposal involves capping the amount people can put into special accounts for health-related spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tumult at the town hall meetings has mostly died down and the debates over socialized medicine have gotten a bit old for everyone. But the fate of a benefit that puts hundreds of millions of dollars in Americans’ pockets each year remained unresolved this week, with senators pitching in with suggestions to keep as much money as possible in the hands of their constituents.

articles.headline: From Obama, G-20’s Mission as Tim Sees It
articles.snippet: An imagined pitch from President Obama in Pittsburgh, jawboning his peers on the need for more bank capital.
articles.abstract: An imagined pitch from President Obama in Pittsburgh, jawboning his peers on the need for more bank capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: Good morning, Nicolas. Did you sleep well, Angela? Wasn’t that a good dinner last night, Gordon? Pittsburgh is such a great city; I’m so glad we’re holding our G-20 summit here. It was Michelle’s idea, you know. I think she would have lobbied for Pittsburgh even if the city hadn’t swung for me in the election. O.K., maybe not.

articles.headline: China’s Threat Revives Race for Rare Minerals
articles.snippet: Talk of a possible ban from China has made other nations put an urgent focus on mining so-called rare earths.
articles.abstract: Talk of a possible ban from China has made other nations put an urgent focus on mining so-called rare earths.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  A Chinese threat to halt exports of rare minerals  vital for high-performance electric motors in wind turbines, hybrid cars and missiles  appears to have backfired.

articles.headline: Health Concerns Over Popular Contraceptives
articles.snippet: Critics say Yaz and Yasmin, the top-selling birth control line in the U.S., pose greater health risks to women.
articles.abstract: Critics say Yaz and Yasmin, the top-selling birth control line in the U.S., pose greater health risks to women.
articles.lead_paragraph: The oral contraceptives Yaz and Yasmin are the top-selling pharmaceutical line for Bayer HealthCare, largely as a result of marketing that presents them as much more than mere pregnancy prevention.

articles.headline: A Critic Finds Obama Policies a Perfect Target
articles.snippet: Americans for Limited Government, a conservative advocacy group, is demonstrating how valuable it can be to have a well-defined enemy.
articles.abstract: Americans for Limited Government, a conservative advocacy group, is demonstrating how valuable it can be to have a well-defined enemy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRFAX, Va.  It is the weekly research meeting at Americans for Limited Government, and Bill Wilson is presiding with gusto. The Obama administration is serving up so many rich targets that Mr. Wilson and his crew of young conservatives hardly know where to begin.

articles.headline: Cryptic Note Ignited an Iran Nuclear Strategy Debate
articles.snippet: The Obama administration seized upon Iran’s disclosure of a nuclear site to marshal its own evidence and try to persuade wavering nations to take a hard line with the country.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration seized upon Iran’s disclosure of a nuclear site to marshal its own evidence and try to persuade wavering nations to take a hard line with the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH  On Tuesday evening in New York, top officials of the world nuclear watchdog agency approached two of President Obama’s senior advisers to deliver the news: Iran had just sent a cryptic letter describing a small “pilot” nuclear facility that the country had never before declared.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: U.S. to Demand Inspection of New Iran Plant ‘Within Weeks’
articles.snippet: The Obama administration plans to tell Iran this week that it must soon open a newly revealed nuclear enrichment site to international inspectors, according to senior officials.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration plans to tell Iran this week that it must soon open a newly revealed nuclear enrichment site to international inspectors, according to senior officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration plans to tell Iran this week that it must open a newly revealed nuclear enrichment site to international inspectors “within weeks,” according to senior administration officials. The administration will also tell Tehran that inspectors must have full access to the key personnel who put together the clandestine plant and to the documents surrounding its construction, the officials said Saturday.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Plan to Boost Afghan Forces Splits Obama Advisers
articles.snippet: Some of the civilian advisers President Obama respects most have deep reservations about sending more troops.
articles.abstract: Some of the civilian advisers President Obama respects most have deep reservations about sending more troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama weighs sending more troops to Afghanistan, one of the most consequential decisions of his presidency, he has discovered that the military is not monolithic in support of the plan and that some of the civilian advisers he respects most have deep reservations.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Enter the Recession’s Waiting Room
articles.snippet: In a factory town in Nebraska, workers and companies alike are in callback limbo.
articles.abstract: In a factory town in Nebraska, workers and companies alike are in callback limbo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Columbus, Neb.

articles.headline: China’s Mr. Wu Keeps Talking
articles.snippet: With critiques of the government and its half-socialist economy, the economist Wu Jinglian seems to be testing what Beijing will allow.
articles.abstract: With critiques of the government and its half-socialist economy, the economist Wu Jinglian seems to be testing what Beijing will allow.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT 79, Wu Jinglian is considered China’s most famous economist.

articles.headline: The Mortgage Machine Backfires
articles.snippet: A ruling last month against the Mortgage Electronic Registration System has significant implications for both the mortgage industry and troubled borrowers.
articles.abstract: A ruling last month against the Mortgage Electronic Registration System has significant implications for both the mortgage industry and troubled borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH the mortgage bust approaching Year Three, it is increasingly up to the nation’s courts to examine the dubious practices that guided the mania. A ruling that the Kansas Supreme Court issued last month has done precisely that, and it has significant implications for both the mortgage industry and troubled borrowers.

articles.headline: Wartime Soldier, Conflicted Mom
articles.snippet: The U.S. military has in large part adapted to women fighting successfully alongside men. Motherhood, though, poses a more formidable challenge.
articles.abstract: The U.S. military has in large part adapted to women fighting successfully alongside men. Motherhood, though, poses a more formidable challenge.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Specialist Jaymie Holschlag returned home after 12 months in Iraq, a new set of children awaited her.

articles.headline: U.S. Job Seekers Exceed Openings by Record Ratio
articles.snippet: Unemployed Americans now confront a job market that is bleaker than ever in the current recession, and employment prospects are still getting worse.
articles.abstract: Unemployed Americans now confront a job market that is bleaker than ever in the current recession, and employment prospects are still getting worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite signs that the economy has resumed growing, unemployed Americans now confront a job market that is bleaker than ever in the current recession, and employment prospects are still getting worse.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Seeking a Range of Sanctions Against Iran
articles.snippet: The sanctions could include a cutoff of investments to the Iranian oil-and-gas industry and restrictions on many more banks than those currently blacklisted.
articles.abstract: The sanctions could include a cutoff of investments to the Iranian oil-and-gas industry and restrictions on many more banks than those currently blacklisted.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is scrambling to assemble a package of harsher economic sanctions against Iran over its nuclear program that could include a cutoff of investments to the country’s oil-and-gas industry and restrictions on many more Iranian banks than those currently blacklisted, senior administration officials said Sunday.

articles.headline: Abbott in $6.6 Billion Deal for Drug Unit
articles.snippet: Abbott Pharmaceuticals announced a deal to acquire the prescription drug unit of Solvay.
articles.abstract: Abbott Pharmaceuticals announced a deal to acquire the prescription drug unit of Solvay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The big American drug maker Abbott Laboratories said Monday that it would acquire the prescription drug unit of the Belgian company Solvay in a deal worth about $6.6 billion in cash and take sole possession of their shared cholesterol drug venture.

articles.headline: Sprint Banks on WiMax to Win Back Market Share
articles.snippet: The next generation of mobile technology promises to deliver faster Internet service, and Sprint is aiming to be first on the scene.
articles.abstract: The next generation of mobile technology promises to deliver faster Internet service, and Sprint is aiming to be first on the scene.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sprint Nextel has taken to boasting that it offers “the first wireless 4G network.”

articles.headline: Nannies Get Holiday. Rich Families Get a Suite.
articles.snippet: Their domestic workers out for Ramadan, Indonesia’s wealthy are on their own; many check into hotels.
articles.abstract: Their domestic workers out for Ramadan, Indonesia’s wealthy are on their own; many check into hotels.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Every year at the end of Ramadan, millions of maids, nannies and chauffeurs make their annual pilgrimages to their hometowns across Indonesia, leaving their pampered employers to fend for themselves.

articles.headline: E-Records Get a Big Endorsement
articles.snippet: The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System will offer its doctors subsidies of up to $40,000 to go to digital patient records.
articles.abstract: The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System will offer its doctors subsidies of up to $40,000 to go to digital patient records.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s drive toward computerized medical records is getting a push from big hospitals, which hope not only to improve patient care but to gain an edge on competitors.

articles.headline: Truckers Insist on Keeping Computers in the Cab
articles.snippet: The industry says computers that connect drivers to dispatchers can be used safely and should be exempt from legislation.
articles.abstract: The industry says computers that connect drivers to dispatchers can be used safely and should be exempt from legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Crisscrossing the country, hundreds of thousands of long-haul truckers use computers in their cabs to get directions and stay in close contact with dispatchers, saving precious minutes that might otherwise be spent at the side of the road.

articles.headline: The Moguls of Mirage, Now Muted
articles.snippet: They have mystical reputations for lording over huge media conglomerates and our cultural consciousness. But this has little to do with their ability to return value to their shareholders.
articles.abstract: They have mystical reputations for lording over huge media conglomerates and our cultural consciousness. But this has little to do with their ability to return value to their shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The moguls were out in full frolic on Tuesday at Michael’s, the ego gymnasium of Manhattan media. Not only was Bill Clinton in the house, hosting some folks from his Global Summit, but so were Barry Diller of IAC/InterActiveCorp, Peter A. Chernin, formerly the president of the News Corporation, Jeffrey L. Bewkes, who runs Time Warner, and Edgar Bronfman Jr., head of the Warner Music Group.

articles.headline: Cuts Meet a Culture of Spending at Condé Nast
articles.snippet: With caviar and $1,000 nightly expense limits, cost-cutting has not been the same as at other publishers.
articles.abstract: With caviar and $1,000 nightly expense limits, cost-cutting has not been the same as at other publishers.
articles.lead_paragraph: At Condé Nast, it is consultants versus car service.

articles.headline: Many Investors Still Avoid Risks of Iraq
articles.snippet: The experience of one Iraqi company shows that economic development and foreign investment face more obstacles than security alone.
articles.abstract: The experience of one Iraqi company shows that economic development and foreign investment face more obstacles than security alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAQUBA, Iraq  The Diyala State Company for Electrical Industries here staggers along, making transformers, spark plugs, ceiling fans and steam irons that few want or can afford anymore.

articles.headline: New Cheney Taking Stage for the G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Liz Cheney, daughter of the former vice president, is entertaining questions about a run for office.
articles.abstract: Liz Cheney, daughter of the former vice president, is entertaining questions about a run for office.

articles.headline: Xerox Buys Affiliated, Fueling Shift to Services
articles.snippet: Business realities are changing for big technology suppliers as corporate customers depend less on products and more on services.
articles.abstract: Business realities are changing for big technology suppliers as corporate customers depend less on products and more on services.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ursula M. Burns, the chief executive of Xerox, declared on Monday that the company’s plan to buy Affiliated Computer Services, an outsourcing services company, for $6.4 billion would be “a game-changer” for Xerox.
